title: 105_hr3921
content: The Act titled "Federal Financial Assistance Management Improvement Act of 1998" is cited in Section 1. Section 2 outlines the findings. The findings in Section 2 of the Act highlight the need to streamline and simplify Federal financial assistance programs to improve service delivery. The purposes of this Act are to improve the effectiveness and performance of Federal financial assistance programs, simplify application and reporting requirements, enhance service delivery to the public, and promote greater coordination among service providers. In this Act, the term "common rule" refers to a government-wide uniform rule for requirements across Federal financial assistance programs. The term "Director" means the Director of the Office of Management and Budget. "Federal agency" refers to any agency defined under section 551(1) of title 5, United States Code. "Federal financial assistance program" means a domestic assistance program under which financial assistance is available to a State, local, or tribal entity. The term "qualified organization" refers to a private, nonprofit organization described in section 501(c)(3) of the Internal Revenue Code, available to carry out activities consistent with national policy goals. The term "local government" includes political subdivisions of a State, combinations of political subdivisions, or local educational agencies. The term "State" refers to each of the 50 States, the District of Columbia, Puerto Rico, American Samoa, Guam, and the Virgin Islands. The term "tribal government" is defined as the governing entity of an Indian tribe under the Indian Self Determination and Education Assistance Act. SEC. 5. DUTIES OF THE DIRECTOR. The Director, in consultation with agency heads, shall direct, coordinate, and assist Federal agencies in establishing a uniform application for multiple Federal financial assistance programs, streamline administrative procedures, and implement an electronic application process. The Act aims to improve coordination and information sharing among Federal agencies regarding the use of funds from Federal financial assistance programs. This includes implementing common rules, enhancing interagency cooperation, strengthening information management capacity, and setting specific annual goals. The Director will establish annual goals and objectives to advance the Act's purposes. Actions taken must comply with statutory requirements for Federal financial assistance programs. The Director may appoint a lead agency and utilize interagency working groups for assistance. Additionally, the Director will review agency plans and reports for adequacy and monitor their progress towards achieving set goals. The Director will establish annual goals and objectives to advance the Act's purposes, ensuring compliance with statutory requirements for Federal financial assistance programs. Agency plans will be reviewed for adequacy, and progress towards goals will be monitored. The Director may exempt agencies with few financial assistance programs from the Act's requirements. A report on implementation will be submitted to Congress within 3 years of enactment. The Director will issue guidance to Federal agencies on implementing the Act within 120 days of enactment, including common rules to be standardized. SEC. 6. DUTIES OF FEDERAL AGENCIES. Each Federal agency must develop and implement a plan within 18 months of this Act's enactment. The plan should streamline application procedures, demonstrate interagency participation, use a uniform application system, designate a lead agency official, and allow electronic application and reporting for financial assistance programs. Each Federal agency must develop and implement a plan within 18 months of this Act's enactment to strengthen information resources management capacity and establish annual goals and objectives in cooperation with State, local, and tribal governments. The plan should be consistent with statutory requirements for Federal financial assistance programs. Each Federal agency must publish and receive public comment on a plan in the Federal Register, hold public hearings, and consult with State, local, and tribal governments during plan development. Each Federal agency is required to submit the plan developed to the Director and Congress, reporting annually on its implementation and performance in meeting specified goals. The report can be included in general management reports as required by law. The Director will contract with the National Academy of Public Administration to evaluate the effectiveness of the Act, including assessing agency performance and coordination among various entities. The evaluation must be submitted to the lead agency, Director, and Congress within 4 years of the Act's enactment. SEC. 8. EFFECTIVE DATE AND SUNSET. This Act will be in effect upon enactment and will expire 5 years after enactment.
